title: Former Bake Off host Sue Perkins reveals she 'doesn't really like cake'
text:
Former Bake Off presenter Sue Perkins has revealed that she 'doesn't really like cake'.

The 50-year-old comedian fronted the popular programme with co-host Mel Giedroyc, 51, for six years before it moved over from the BBC to Channel 4 in 2016.

She admitted that although she's eaten 'a couple of tons' of baked goods while hosting the show, the treat 'isn't her go-to' and she would only eat a cake made by pal and former judge Mary Berry, 84, if she 'had to'.

Former Bake Off presenter Sue Perkins has revealed that despite hosting the show for several years, she 'doesn't really like cake'

The 50-year-old comedian says she would only eat a cake made by pal and former Bake Off judge Mary Berry, 84, (pictured) if she 'had to'

Speaking to the Cheltenham Literature Festival, she said: 'I shouldn't say this but I don't really like cake. I don't mind it.

'I've eaten a couple of tons of it. I can sense it's made with love and I can appreciate it but it's not my go to.'

She then revealed if push came to shove, it's 'got to be a Mary Berry', adding: 'I would say the lemon drizzle cake is pure excellence', reports the Sunday Times.

Both Sue and Mel quit the baking competition, alongside Mary, when the show made the controversial move to Channel 4 and were replaced by Noel Fielding and Sandi Toksvig, while Mary was succeeded by Prue Leith.

Mel previously confessed that she hadn't been tuning in to see her former colleague Paul Hollywood on the new show, and has no regrets about leaving.

Both Sue and Mel quit the baking competition, alongside Mary, when the show made the controversial move to Channel 4 however judge Paul Hollywood decided to stick with the show

Mel and Sue were replaced by Noel Fielding (far left) and Sandi Toksvig (left) while Mary was replaced by Prue Leith (far right)

'No I haven't [watched it]. I feel bad!' she said when asked if she was watching the new series.

And when prompted on whether she regretted bidding farewell to the series, she added: 'Not at all!'

Mel also revealed her decision to leave the show took her just 'three seconds' after she was told it would no longer air on the BBC.

'I think there was no question where we were heading, but I miss the gang... we were like a big family,' she said in 2018.

Mel previously confessed that she hadn't been tuning in to see her former colleague, Paul on the new show, and has no regrets about leaving

Earlier this year it was announced that the show would be staying put on Channel 4 after they signed a two-year contract with the much loved show, with the new deal ensuring Love Productions are keeping Bake Off on the channel until at least 2021.

Love Productions’ chief executive Richard McKerrow said: 'We are delighted to have extended Bake Off’s stay on Channel 4 after two great years together.

'We have been hugely encouraged by the audience response and feedback the show has received during its time on Channel 4 and are thrilled to be bringing Junior Bake Off to the Channel.

'It seems particularly appropriate to be announcing news of the extension on Channel 4 as we enjoy Bake Off’s tenth anniversary on British television.'

Channel 4 snapped up Bake Off from the BBC in 2016, with the broadcaster acquiring the show in a reported £75 million deal.
description: Former Great British Bake Off presenter Sue Perkins, 50, has revealed that despite hosting the show for several years, she 'doesn't really like cake' and would only eat a Mary Berry one if she had to.
